Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs and Co-PIs of grants supported through the NSF-NIH-ANR-BMBF-BSF-NICT Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) program meet annually to report on projects; to discuss scientific, educational, and program-related issues; and to develop a cohesive investigator community representing many different approaches to computational neuroscience. This fourteenth meeting of CRCNS investigators brings together a broad spectrum of computational neuroscience researchers supported by the program, and includes poster presentations, talks, plenary lectures, and workshops.

The meeting is scheduled for June 13-15, 2018 and is hosted by the University of California, Berkeley. More information is available at https://www.regonline.com/crcns2018.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 Collaborative Research in Computational Neuroscience (CRCNS) PI Meeting took place from June 13-15, 2018, in Berkeley, CA, and hosted by the University of California, Berkeley. The main meeting, including poster session, was held on June 13thand 14that the Lawrence Hall of Science. The optional workshop on academia-industry collaboration was held on June 15th at Haas School of Business.  
The specific goal of the meeting was to foster interactions between experimental and computational neuroscientists. Computational and quantitative approaches to the study of the brain and nervous system have been a part of neuroscience since its beginnings as a field. However, recent advances in the ability to collect large data sets, in the ability to create and run very large simulations and in the development of new data analysis approaches may soon lead to an even more central role for computational thinking in this field.
The main meeting consisted of a mixture of research talks, panel discussions, and short presentations about broader impacts in computational neuroscience. The audience consisted of a total of 112 registered attendees from 60 institutions across US, France, Germany, Israel, and Japan. The program consisted of 23 scientific talks.  The poster session consisted of 30 posters, which provided opportunity for postdocs and graduate students to present their research to scientific community.  The broader impacts panel discussed ways to engage women and underrepresented minorities in computational and data intensive disciplines.  The optional workshop on academia-industry collaboration included discussion of job opportunities for postdocs and students outside of academia. Conference materials, containing the conference description, photos program, and abstracts, are archived on the website http://crcns2018.berkeley.edu.
